snippet: A pop-up restaurant company is dedicated to the notion that high-end chefs should listen to their customers’ feedback.
lead_paragraph: It was a late July evening, and Christopher Sorter had just finished cooking an exotic five-course meal that included such triple-dare dishes as beef heart ragù and crème brûlée with bone marrow. When the dinner began, there had been some apprehension about the food among the 120 guests who had gathered in a warehouselike space in Silver Spring, Md. But as waiters cleared the last plates, the event had a relieved and jubilant air, as if everyone had just narrowly dodged a bus.

lead_paragraph: This unexpected dip is a terrific way to use ripe avocados when guacamole isn’t an option. It’s mild, creamy, and perfectly balanced between sweet and tart. The only downside is that it only keeps for about day in the fridge, so plan on making it the night before packing it into someone’s lunchbox if that’s its destination. Serve it with pita or tortilla chips, breadsticks and cucumber slices, and double the recipe if you’re feeding a crowd.

snippet: Liane Moriarty, whose “Big Little Lies” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, realized something while reading “Fifty Shades of Grey”: “I couldn’t write a sexy spanking scene to save my life.”
lead_paragraph: Coming Clean: The Australian novelist Liane Moriarty, like a lot of writers, is ambivalent about modern technology. “I have social media anxiety,” she confessed on her blog last year, and she wasn’t kidding — that post, dated May 6, 2013, remains her most recent as this column goes to press, and the blog as a whole has averaged just a handful of entries per year since it began in 2010. Too bad, since Moriarty turns out to be a natural blogger, droll and daffy and confiding. Here she is, for instance, on reading “Fifty Shades of Grey”: “Why didn’t any of you lovely readers tell me that you wanted more spanking? (Ha.) . . . Maybe you realized that I couldn’t write a sexy spanking scene to save my life. (Well, I don’t know. Perhaps I could to save my life. Except I’d be quite nervous and distracted by the person trying to kill me.)” Moriarty does maintain an active presence on Facebook, where, to promote her latest novel, “Big Little Lies” — new at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list — she recently asked readers to reveal little lies of their own. “My publishers asked me to get in the spirit of things by also making a confession,” she wrote, “so here’s one: When my son’s kindergarten class was putting together a recipe book of ‘favorite easy recipes’ I sent in a nutritious-sounding avocado muffin recipe that I had never made in my life just so I would look like a good mother.”
abstract: Liane Moriarty, whose “Big Little Lies” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, realized something while reading “Fifty Shades of Grey”: “I couldn’t write a sexy spanking scene to save my life.”

snippet: At the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, on Beach 87th Street in Queens, the usual oceanside austerity has been elevated into a sort of laid-back chic.
lead_paragraph: Beach cuisine, generally speaking, is not known for its imagination or distinction: There are sturdy standbys (pizza, fish tacos) and serviceable snacks (nachos, chips and guacamole). But at the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, a happy little shack on Beach 87th Street in Queens, the usual oceanside austerity has been elevated into a sort of laid-back chic. The restaurant’s owners, Brady Walsh, a tattooed city firefighter, and Brandon D’Leo, a sculptor with elaborate hair, have adorned their joint with colorful surfing murals and, perhaps for balance’s sake, an art installation that is part of this summer’s Rockaway! show sponsored by MoMA PS1 and others. The chef, Patrick Quinn, meanwhile has equipped his menu with kale and quinoa and sriracha-dipped chicken wings. On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Surf Club’s outdoor patio was filled with suntanned brunchgoers eating meals from paper-lined baskets before walking the few short blocks to the beach.
abstract: At the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, on Beach 87th Street in Queens, the usual oceanside austerity has been elevated into a sort of laid-back chic.

snippet: The implications of entrenched inequality described by the economist Thomas Piketty extend beyond the realm of political economy.
lead_paragraph: “Capital in the 21st Century,” by the French economist Thomas Piketty, has become this year’s most unlikely best seller, a crossover from the world of scholarship into general public discussion of a kind that seems rarer than it used to be. The book’s thesis — that economic inequality in the developed world is increasing, with potentially dire consequences for social justice and democratic governance — has struck a nerve in the American body politic. But its implications extend beyond the realm of political economy. Though it is expectedly dry, careful and data-driven, the book invites the re-examination of deeply held assumptions about the world.
abstract: The implications of entrenched inequality described by the economist Thomas Piketty extend beyond the realm of political economy.

snippet: While restaurants take a more casual, accessible approach, creativity still sparkles on the plate.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that dining out in Barcelona means bouncing from one Michelin-starred restaurant to the next, with chefs like Ferran and Albert Adrià and Albert Raurich leading the way. But as the Spanish economy has suffered in recent years, the fine-dining scene has hit its share of road bumps. Tourism, in large part, has been able to sustain many of the great temples of Spanish cuisine, though not all have survived. Can Fabes, a restaurant outside of Barcelona that earned three Michelin stars every year from 1994 to 2011, closed in August, while Madrid’s two-star restaurant Sergi Arola Gastro closed months before, after owing back taxes (though it has since reopened). Albert Adrià has even gone as far as to say that “the high gastronomy formula doesn’t work now.”
abstract: While restaurants take a more casual, accessible approach, creativity still sparkles on the plate.

snippet: A sweet, fruity flavor and a mix of textures set this salsa apart. It goes great with salmon or just about any other fish.
lead_paragraph: This is a sweet, fruity salsa, with a wonderful array of textures: juicy, sweet-acidic pineapple; soft, creamy and subtle avocado; and crisp and refreshing jicama, with everything set off by the heat of the chiles. The avocado gives a pale green cast to the mix. It looks beautiful with salmon and goes with just about any other fish, as well as with chicken or even fajitas.

lead_paragraph: Luxury at the Mayflower Grace hotel, in the Litchfield County town of Washington, is embodied in its parklike setting, by its two-story antique-laden entrance foyer, and by its spa services that go well beyond massages, facials and miscellaneous scrubs and wraps. snippet: For Sarah Johnson, the director of Weill Music Institute, Sunday is a day to spend with her boyfriend and her cat, if she’s not busy working a weekend music event.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Johnson is the director of Weill Music Institute, Carnegie Hall’s education and community engagement enterprise, which has a staff of 25, a budget of $10 million and a reach of 450,000 people in New York and around the world. Among other duties, she oversees the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America, for musicians ages 16 to 19 who come to Purchase, N.Y., from all over the country for a two-week training residency. The ensemble’s eight-city 2014 tour opens at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College on July 20 and at Carnegie Hall on July 22. Ms. Johnson, 38, lives in a Park Slope brownstone with her cat, Caterina, and spends Sundays catching up with her boyfriend, Danyon Davis, 39, an actor, director and teacher, who lives nearby.
abstract: For Sarah Johnson, the director of Weill Music Institute, Sunday is a day to spend with her boyfriend and her cat, if she’s not busy working a weekend music event.

snippet: On the south shore, two extraordinary chefs joined Lo for a day of paddling kayaks through the bay, digging for soft-shell clams and throwing together a summery feast.
lead_paragraph: At around 4:30 in the afternoon, when the tide is low on the south shore of Long Island, April Bloomfield, Elizabeth Falkner and Anita Lo carry kayaks down to the water. There’s no path, so they make their own as they go, clearing tall, wild sea grass with the viciously sharp blade of a scythe that Lo picked up in Hong Kong. Then they climb into their boats and glide away. A school of mirrored shiners moves past. Plovers hop around the frothy shore and small, see-through jellyfish float by, but the chefs are not distracted. They came to dig clams for dinner. “This looks good,” Lo says, when they reach a grassy island in the middle of the cove. “Let’s drop our anchors.”
abstract: On the south shore, two extraordinary chefs joined Lo for a day of paddling kayaks through the bay, digging for soft-shell clams and throwing together a summery feast.

snippet: Refried heirloom vaquero beans add a special touch to these tostadas, but black beans work, too.
lead_paragraph: I have always had a weakness for black bean tostadas. These are not unlike Oaxacan tlayudas, though this recipe doesn’t call for that dish’s signature extra-large corn tortillas. I used luxurious black and white vaqueros from Rancho Gordo for these, but black beans will also work well. Cook them yourself (don’t use canned), because you’ll need the delicious broth. I don’t refry them for as long as I normally would because I like them moist, and vaqueros are starchier than black beans.
abstract: Refried heirloom vaquero beans add a special touch to these tostadas, but black beans work, too.

lead_paragraph: Refried heirloom vaquero beans add a special touch to these tostadas, but black beans work, too. I have always had a weakness for black bean tostadas. These are not unlike Oaxacan tlayudas, though this recipe doesn’t call for that dish’s signature extra-large corn tortillas. I used luxurious black and white vaqueros from Rancho Gordo for these, but black beans will also work well. Cook them yourself (don’t use canned), because you’ll need the delicious broth. I don’t refry them for as long as I normally would because I like them moist, and vaqueros are starchier than black beans.

snippet: The food at the recently reopened Tavern on the Green does not live up to the setting.
lead_paragraph: Restaurant critics are supposed to be impartial, but I can’t help feeling some proprietary interest in Tavern on the Green. Not a financial interest, except insofar as a profitable Tavern is good for the city’s budget, which, in a fractions-of-pennies way, is good for me as a grumpy taxpayer. It’s more like a civic interest. Tavern on the Green belongs to the city and sits inside the most beautiful public park in which I’ve ever rowed, cycled, struck out in softball, misidentified a confusing fall warbler and illegally consumed alcoholic beverages. I’d let the city keep those fractional pennies if that helped Tavern on the Green live up to its setting.
abstract: The food at the recently reopened Tavern on the Green does not live up to the setting.

snippet: The grassy flavor of quinoa works well with cilantro in this main-dish salad.
lead_paragraph: I love the versatility of quinoa. It can be the building-block ingredient for a salad, as it is in this main-dish salad, or it can be added to salads in smaller amounts, almost as a garnish. Its grassy flavor marries well with cilantro, itself an herb with a grassy, though more pungent, taste. I added sieved hard-boiled eggs for protein – though you could leave them out if you want to make a vegan version of this dish, and toasted pumpkin seeds for crunch.
abstract: The grassy flavor of quinoa works well with cilantro in this main-dish salad.

lead_paragraph:
The grassy flavor of quinoa works well with cilantro in this main-dish salad.
I love the versatility of quinoa. It can be the building-block ingredient for a salad, as it is in this main-dish salad, or it can be added to salads in smaller amounts, almost as a garnish. Its grassy flavor marries well with cilantro, itself an herb with a grassy, though more pungent, taste. I added sieved hard-boiled eggs for protein – though you could leave them out if you want to make a vegan version of this dish, and toasted pumpkin seeds for crunch. 
Another ingredient that contributes crunch as well as color is the soaked split red lentils. They also contribute more protein to an already high-protein grain. They are optional –  make this salad whether or not you have the lentils.

snippet: The meat-loving Ruder family loved the lasagna, the Big Bowl with Greens, and the beans. The family’s primary cooked loved planning ahead for leftovers.
lead_paragraph: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, they tried a Big Bowl with Black Beans, Greens, Avocado and Salsa Fresca.

snippet: All-day breakfasts have been making a comeback on Long Island, with several new cafes upgrading traditional diner offerings with locally sourced ingredients and made-from-scratch recipes.
lead_paragraph: After years of catering to night owls with pub offerings like the Good Life in Massapequa Park and the Phoenix in Seaford, Peter Mangouranes, 38, and Paul Oliva, 35, decided to introduce themselves to customers who like to socialize before the sun sets with an all-day breakfast spot called Jam. The cheerful, eight-month-old country cafe, just down the block from the Good Life, has been serving breakfast standards with a twist since October.
abstract: All-day breakfasts have been making a comeback on Long Island, with several new cafes upgrading traditional diner offerings with locally sourced ingredients and made-from-scratch recipes.

lead_paragraph: A place that bills itself as a cantina, as this nearly year-old spot does, calls to mind a few assumptions. First, that a good time will be had there. snippet: This small township 20 miles northwest of San Francisco is isolated by temperament as well as geography — but for how long?
lead_paragraph: The Grand Hotel is neither, really. Forty-five years ago — before the poets Robert Creeley and Lawrence Ferlinghetti bought houses nearby; before a food co-op and a naturopathic store opened down the street; before the rustic surfing town of Bolinas, Calif., was the sort of place where a tourist would consider spending the night — the Grand Hotel was merely Vic Amoroso’s house, with a garage that doubled as a bric-a-brac shop.
abstract: This small township 20 miles northwest of San Francisco is isolated by temperament as well as geography — but for how long?

lead_paragraph: Particularly dramatic and romantic at sunset, the view from the Half Moon restaurant’s many vantage points is inspiring. The promenade deck is so close to the Hudson River that when the wind is up, guests might be refreshed by the spray from a crashing wave.

lead_paragraph: At El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette, you can get this rich, silky egg terrine all day long, but it’s particularly wonderful at breakfast or brunch. Although it does take time to put together, you can do all of it well ahead – up to 24 hours. And the last minute work is minimal (slice an avocado, chop up some fresh herbs). Don’t be tempted to skip the frequent stirring while the dish bakes. It may seem fussy, but in fact is the key to the luscious texture, which is somewhere between custard and bread pudding.

snippet: Laredo, Tex., along the Mexican border, where Interstate 35 begins its path, faces extreme challenges to meld two cultures, an evolution occurring in cities and towns nationwide.
lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex. — The state’s standardized test approached like a spring storm, and Alina Quiroga knew her fourth graders could drown. Here at a school about a mile from Mexico along Interstate 35, most of her students rarely speak English outside class. Many, living with distant relatives, lack the confidence to speak up even in Spanish. Ms. Quiroga circled the room, her pearl drop earrings swaying, as the children read aloud about George Washington.
abstract: Laredo, Tex., along the Mexican border, where Interstate 35 begins its path, faces extreme challenges to meld two cultures, an evolution occurring in cities and towns nationwide.

snippet: This Chelsea tapas spot has grown in size and scope.
lead_paragraph: The name means “the fifth pine,” a Spanish idiom for the boondocks, which was probably a stretch even seven years ago when El Quinto Pino opened on West 24th Street, across from the canyon wall of London Terrace. The thumbnail curve of the sardine-can tapas bar is just the way it’s been since the beginning, packed, every seat there and on the opposite wall a few inches away taken almost any time you show up.
abstract: This Chelsea tapas spot has grown in size and scope.

snippet: Out of the minimalist space of El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette on the Lower East Side comes mostly comfort food, unobtrusively finessed.
lead_paragraph: There is no falafel on the falafel plate at El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette. This is not an error. What appears instead could be described on the menu (but thankfully isn’t) as “evanescence of falafel,” and may be the most low-key — and satisfying — example of culinary deconstruction in the city.

snippet: Venture off the eastern coast of Tanzania to stroll through historic Stone Town, listen to a celebrated local music genre and sample one of Zanzibar’s spectacular beaches.
lead_paragraph: The name Zanzibar conjures up visions of sultans’ palaces, paradisiacal beaches and winding alleyways leading to spice-filled bazaars. Indeed, this coral archipelago in the Indian Ocean, 23 miles off the eastern coast of Tanzania, still has many of the features that it did when it was an important trading center and its historic Stone Town served as the capital of an Omani sultanate. Zanzibar’s largest island, Unguja, is home to most of the cultural attractions, many of them found in beguiling Stone Town, which was awarded Unesco World Heritage status in 2000. In recent years, there’s been a concerted effort to restore and give new life to the city’s distinctive structures. Palaces have been turned into museums and cultural centers, and grand Swahili mansions have been reborn as restaurants and boutique hotels. Yet the coast still offers the “delicious view” that the explorer Sir Richard Burton recorded, of a “cocoa-fringed shore of purest white, and the sea blue as a slab of lapis lazuli.” (Note: Prices in Zanzibar are routinely quoted in dollars — alongside, or occasionally instead of, the island’s official currency, the Tanzanian shilling.)
abstract: Venture off the eastern coast of Tanzania to stroll through historic Stone Town, listen to a celebrated local music genre and sample one of Zanzibar’s spectacular beaches.

lead_paragraph:
The crunchy, juicy salad known in the Middle East as fattoush is just one of the region’s many thrifty and tasty uses for day-old or dried-out bread. Stale bread is better than fresh for some dishes because it will absorb more liquid, such as the juices from a ripe tomato or — in this recipe — a lively dressing with mint leaves, lemon juice and a bit of honey to smooth out the flavors. The Israeli-American chef Einat Admony, who created this rewrite of the classic, took the radical step of leaving out the tomato and adding avocado, a very American ingredient.

To make the bread shards very crisp, toast and let cool before breaking. To make them more luxurious, tear up the bread and toast it in a hot skillet with a few tablespoons of olive oil, butter, or both.

snippet: Followers of the spiritual master Sri Chinmoy, who died in 2007, carry on his teachings at vegetarian restaurants and other businesses.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — I ordered the California omelet. It was fresh and capably cooked, with ample, bright green slices of avocado. The service was cheery and efficient. Were it not for the video of an older Bangladeshi immigrant performing heroic acts of strength that was playing on a loop on a flat-screen television, I would have remembered Silence-Heart-Nest, in the Fremont neighborhood of Seattle, as just an above-average vegetarian brunch spot.

snippet: This is the best time of the year for picking up some Hass avocados, the most common type in grocery stores, and putting together these innovative avocado-based dishes.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been reveling in Hass avocados, and now I understand why, having just discovered an article that David Karp, fruit expert extraordinaire, wrote in The Los Angeles Times a few years ago about the optimal time for ripeness in avocados. The California Avocado Commission sets Nov. 28 as the start of the Hass avocado harvest, meaning that the oil content in the fruit is high enough for picking.

snippet: This salsa is closer to a salad, with a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors.
lead_paragraph: This is based on a recipe in Kim Sunée’s wonderful new book, “A Mouthful of Stars” (Andrews McMeel). Her recipe is more of a salad, a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors. I loved the idea of combining avocado and papaya, two subtle, creamy fruits, with crunchy, bright-tasting Asian pears and spicy chiles. The first time I saw the recipe I wanted to test it right away, but I didn’t have Asian pears. So I used an apple, and loved it. It’s the sweet, crunchy fruit that does the trick, and apples and Asian pears both work. There are onions in the original recipe but I’ve made them optional.
abstract: This salsa is closer to a salad, with a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors.

snippet: A salsa with a balance of char, heat, acid and creamy, based on a recipe by Kim Sunée.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite new cookbooks of this season is “A Mouthful of Stars” (Andrews McMeel), by Kim Sunée. The book is a memoir, travelogue and cookbook all rolled into one, written by an author who earlier published another compelling memoir with recipes,“Trail of Crumbs.” Kim is a poetic world traveler who loves many cuisines. She is a big fan of taco trucks and loves salsa, the spicier the better. This salsa is based on her recipe for roasted tomatillo-poblano salsa. I love its balance of char, heat, acid and creamy. I’m a moderate when it comes to heat, but you can make this hotter by adding more chiles.
abstract: A salsa with a balance of char, heat, acid and creamy, based on a recipe by Kim Sunée.

snippet: A chunky guacamole that shows how Indian and Mexican flavors overlap.
lead_paragraph: The chef Suvir Saran says that “avocados make people happy,” and he’s right. He adds toasted cumin seeds, which he refers to as “Indian bacon bits,” to his chunky guacamole. This guacamole has all the flavors of a Mexican guacamole – illustrating yet again how Indian, Middle Eastern, Mediterranean and Mexican cuisines overlap. In fact, the ingredients here are identical to those that I have always used in my guacamole; but this recipe has the added delight of texture, as the ingredients aren’t mashed up.
abstract: A chunky guacamole that shows how Indian and Mexican flavors overlap.

lead_paragraph: Coleslaw meets guacamole here in this utterly simple mix of shredded cabbage, salt, lemon, and puréed avocado. The chef Iliana de la Vega, who was born in Oaxaca, Mexico, served it at a delicious Latin-themed lunch she prepared at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference this year at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. I couldn’t get enough of it. I sat with Iliana at the lunch and asked her about the salad. “Just salt the cabbage, let it sit for a while, then add lots of lemon juice and the mashed avocado,”  she said.  That really is all there is to it. Shred the cabbage thin and for best results let it sit, after salting generously, for an hour or more, to tenderize it and draw out strong-tasting juices.

lead_paragraph: I have been making tomatillo and avocado salsa for years, but I usually simmer the tomatillos rather than roasting them. Roasting the tomatillos, chiles and garlic – toasting really, as I use a skillet for this, on top of the flame –  produces a salsa with a delicious charred flavor. I learned something recently from the chef Iliana de la Vega, who demonstrated the recipe at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference in Napa Valley in March: she says, in no uncertain terms, that you should not add water to tomatillo salsas. Without the water, this is a more intense salsa with pleasing density.You can use it as a sauce to serve with chicken or fish, or as a dip with chips or other vegetables.

lead_paragraph:
With a little advance preparation, this spicy salad can be made in 30 minutes.
You can cook the two kinds of rices together for this spicy Asian salad if you soak the red rice for an hour first. The antioxidant-rich pigment from the red rice will bleed into the white rice, turning it an attractive  pale rusty color, which is nice. The marinade and the rice will keep for about 3 days in the refrigerator. The baked tofu will also keep, in the marinade, for a couple of days.

snippet: At the Vegetable and Fruit Improvement Center at Texas A&M University, the goal is to breed produce that tastes better, has more nutrients and better tolerates weather.
lead_paragraph: In 1983, after more than 10 years of research, a Texas A&M University horticulturist named Leonard Pike created an onion that did not make people cry. This alone was revolutionary, but Dr. Pike also conferred another attribute upon his plant progeny: a single center.

snippet: The indie-rock icon, who left Brooklyn for Hollywood shortly before releasing his new solo album last month, reflects on the joys of Mexican food, tennis and silent movies.
lead_paragraph: For as long as indie rock has been a genre, Dean Wareham has been a part of it. Galaxie 500, the band the New Zealand-born singer and guitarist formed with a pair of Harvard classmates in the late ’80s, informed a generation of shoegazers and remains a make-out-session staple today. Equally beloved is his ’90s dream-pop band Luna, through which he met his wife, the singer and bassist Britta Phillips. Together, they’ve spent the last decade or so writing and touring as Dean & Britta. They’ve also been regular collaborators of the director Noah Baumbach, scoring “The Squid and the Whale” and playing the co-hosts of an awkward dinner party in last year’s “Frances Ha.”
abstract: The indie-rock icon, who left Brooklyn for Hollywood shortly before releasing his new solo album last month, reflects on the joys of Mexican food, tennis and silent movies.

snippet: Highly contagious and hard to kill, norovirus is the leading cause of gastrointestinal infections in the United States, causing an estimated 21 million illnesses and 800 deaths.
lead_paragraph: I have often felt sorry for people whose cruise ship vacations were marred by a nasty gastrointestinal virus that kept them quarantined in their cabins and sometimes cut short the trip.
abstract: Highly contagious and hard to kill, norovirus is the leading cause of gastrointestinal infections in the United States, causing an estimated 21 million illnesses and 800 deaths.

snippet: The concept: coffee, waffles and salads on the menu and no seating inside. The result: Somehow, it works.
lead_paragraph: The premise of Linea Caffe, which opened last September, sounds as if it came straight out of a late-night brainstorming session without a next-morning reality check. A coffee bar (Linea Caffe) shares a tiny storefront with a waffle counter (Lt. Waffle), which also functions as a salad bar. Click on the salad bar’s website, and you’ll find a statement of purpose that reads like a manifesto: avocado is “the zeitgeist,” and “kale is not a passing fad.”
abstract: The concept: coffee, waffles and salads on the menu and no seating inside. The result: Somehow, it works.

snippet: A team of international scientists found no evidence that eating saturated fat, the kind found in meat, butter and cheese, increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.
lead_paragraph: Many of us have long been told that saturated fat, the type found in meat, butter and cheese, causes heart disease. But a large and exhaustive new analysis by a team of international scientists found no evidence that eating saturated fat increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.
abstract: A team of international scientists found no evidence that eating saturated fat, the kind found in meat, butter and cheese, increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.

snippet: Several culinary schools in New Jersey offer sushi-making classes for beginners that teach rice preparation techniques and knife skills. Socializing with others is part of the appeal.
lead_paragraph: At a sushi-making class last month at Chef Central, a retail store with a cooking studio in Paramus, an informal survey of students revealed a spectrum of motivations: Evan Strassberg, 15, of Glen Rock, came because he is an aspiring cook. Sergio Minervini, 54, of River Vale, said he signed up with his wife and daughter “as a family bonding thing.” And Steve Fleischer, 50, of Suffern, N.Y., reserved two spots at the 90-minute class because he thought it was an inventive place to bring a first date.
abstract: Several culinary schools in New Jersey offer sushi-making classes for beginners that teach rice preparation techniques and knife skills. Socializing with others is part of the appeal.

snippet: While cancer proves that we cannot control our bodies, my support group continually reminds me, we can try to guide our minds and spirits.
lead_paragraph: Every Sunday evening, I phone a friend in another college town who has not yet found a cancer support group in her community. Let’s call her Melanie. Melanie had recovered from surgery and completed chemotherapy. Physically, she had gained strength. Yet she continued to feel overwhelmed by negative thoughts.
abstract: While cancer proves that we cannot control our bodies, my support group continually reminds me, we can try to guide our minds and spirits.

snippet: When it comes to beauty products, the actress and singer Zoë Kravitz is all about maintaining a luxuriously bohemian regimen.
lead_paragraph: Zoë Kravitz, 25, the daughter of the singer Lenny Kravitz and the actress Lisa Bonet, has pursued both of her parents’ professions. Her new projects include a supporting role in the soon-to-be-released “Divergent,” an action movie based on the first book in a trilogy of young-adult novels by Veronica Roth. Born in the Venice section of Los Angeles, Ms. Kravitz, who is also a member of the rock band Lolawolf, now lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with the kind of luxuriously bohemian beauty regimen common to each neighborhood.
abstract: When it comes to beauty products, the actress and singer Zoë Kravitz is all about maintaining a luxuriously bohemian regimen.

snippet: The menu at Órale Mexican Kitchen features more adventurous items than are typically found in the standard Mexican-American repertoire.
lead_paragraph: The minute you enter Órale Mexican Kitchen in Jersey City, you can see that the person who decorated it has a fine eye for design. Note, in particular, the beautifully lit bottles of Jarritos soda, in colors that reflect their flavors (lime, strawberry, fruit punch, mandarin and grapefruit). After a flight of tequila and a round of guacamole studded with unexpected treats, like cubes of Cabrales blue cheese or juicy pineapple, you know you are in for more than just visual delights.
abstract: The menu at Órale Mexican Kitchen features more adventurous items than are typically found in the standard Mexican-American repertoire.

snippet: Surrounded by other dining spots in the Woodbury Village Shopping Center, MoCA Asian Bistro has become a place where reservations need to be made well in advance.
lead_paragraph: MoCA Asian Bistro in Woodbury has been drawing crowds since its opening two months ago. When I called two days ahead for a Friday or Saturday reservation, I was told that none were available, no matter how early or late. I settled for a Saturday night reservation 10 days in the future and was given a choice of 6 or 6:30 p.m.
abstract: Surrounded by other dining spots in the Woodbury Village Shopping Center, MoCA Asian Bistro has become a place where reservations need to be made well in advance.

snippet: On the last day of London Fashion Week, the personal trainer Russell Bateman shares the wellness tips he usually reserves for his model clientele.
lead_paragraph: Spider crawls, crab walks, monkey jumps, ski-sits: These playful moves may sound better suited to grade-school physical education than a hardcore workout, but ahead-of-the-fitness-curve British celebrities and models are intimately familiar with them. The exercises were created by Russell Bateman, a personal trainer who founded theSBC gym in London — where the only thing more motivating than the grueling regimen is the array of impossibly toned, A-list bodies in the room.
abstract: On the last day of London Fashion Week, the personal trainer Russell Bateman shares the wellness tips he usually reserves for his model clientele.

snippet: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers new recipes that make use of those bags of beans lying around the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: If you are good about keeping a well-stocked pantry, you probably have some bags of beans lying around. From time to time, check the “best before” date on the bags. Or if you buy in bulk and put the beans into jars, put a little sticker on the jars with the date you purchased the beans. Although dried beans won’t spoil, older beans can become hard and brittle, and sometimes they don’t soften properly when you cook them.
abstract: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers new recipes that make use of those bags of beans lying around the kitchen.

snippet: At this diminutive restaurant in Carroll Gardens, it’s best to come with a party large enough to order every seafood dish.
lead_paragraph: The kitchen measures 3 feet by 5 feet and has no oven, only a few induction burners and a sandwich press. There is barely room for the two men in black aprons (the chef, Andrew D’Ambrosi, and his sous-chef, Anthony Mongeluzzi) who toil, heads bowed, behind a long glass case filled with gleaming slabs of raw fish.

lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Nanette Lepore, 49, who recently dressed New York Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray, and their daughter, Chiara de Blasio, for his inauguration ceremony, is releasing a line of products for the home this month. snippet: RameNesque, a Japanese cafe, fits right in with the homespun gestalt that is part of Peekskill’s charm.
lead_paragraph: On two different visits to RameNesque, a new Japanese cafe with a brisk takeout business in downtown Peekskill, we couldn’t get our table to stand still. Despite our best efforts — jamming folded paper napkins under the stand, jostling the table this way and that — the wobbles won out. Chopsticks, water glasses, ramen bowls, ramekins — all skittered around on the high-gloss wooden table top like so many pointers on a Ouija board.
abstract: RameNesque, a Japanese cafe, fits right in with the homespun gestalt that is part of Peekskill’s charm.

snippet: A four-month-old pan-Asian lounge on Merrick Road offers sushi, cooked dishes and some unexpected textures.
lead_paragraph: Patrons at 2one2, a pan-Asian restaurant named for its address on Merrick Road in Rockville Centre, enter through the bar. snippet: Helen Yoest wrote a book about natural aphrodisiacs called “Plants With Benefits.”
lead_paragraph: Helen Yoest didn’t set out, as she said recently, to write a horticultural Kama Sutra. It was sort of an accident. Ms. Yoest, a garden writer, was researching an article on avocados when she learned that the fruit was considered an aphrodisiac. What makes it so, she wondered: The nutrients? The shape? Bingo. Turns out their reputation dates to the Aztecs, who marveled at how avocados grew in pairs, and named the plant “the testicle tree.”
abstract: Helen Yoest wrote a book about natural aphrodisiacs called “Plants With Benefits.”

snippet: Forgoing the baby food in favor of letting a baby feed herself means more mess. It also means parents can enjoy their meals while baby eats, too.
lead_paragraph: “You need a class to tell you how to feed your baby?” my dad laughed down the line to London, where I live. I was en route to a workshop on introducing my six-month-old daughter to solid food and was hoping to find clarity on which approach to use: traditional purées or this thing called “baby-led weaning” I’d heard English moms chatting about. Some swore by it, but others derided it as just another silly offshoot of bohemian urban parenting. It was like breast versus bottle 2.0, and I wanted to know more.
abstract: Forgoing the baby food in favor of letting a baby feed herself means more mess. It also means parents can enjoy their meals while baby eats, too.

snippet: The South African city is dotted with hybrid businesses, from clothing shops that serve food to a laundry that doubles as a dim sum bar.
lead_paragraph: Step in to I Love My Laundry in Heritage Square in Cape Town, and you’ll think you’ve entered a glamorous wine bar or supper club. You’d be only partly right. The narrow room is dominated by a communal table flanked by 16 upholstered high-back chairs, and at a glance it seems that the only nod to the location’s peculiar name is the clotheslines strung with artwork, prints and pillowcases for sale, or the price tags attached to wine bottles with clothespins. But listen closely and you just might hear the whir of washing machines. I Love My Laundry is a dim sum bar. And an art and wine shop. And a weekly private fondue party. It’s also a front — literally — for a laundromat. In fact, laundry delivery is the core business.
abstract: The South African city is dotted with hybrid businesses, from clothing shops that serve food to a laundry that doubles as a dim sum bar.

snippet: Notable offerings at K60 Japanese Steak House, which has a lively hibachi room and a quiet sushi bar, include steak teriyaki and an arrangement of sliced white tuna.
lead_paragraph: The first thing to know about K60 Japanese Steak House is that this sprawling, neon-trimmed restaurant in a Lake Grove strip mall offers two entirely different dining experiences. The most popular, by far, is the raucous hibachi room, where flames leap, diners cheer (or cringe), servers scurry and impassioned chefs jump, juggle, chop and grill, all beneath the nonstop whoosh of overhead exhaust fans. And there is the adjacent, far quieter “sushi room,” as a hostess called it on a recent evening, with its sleek, sparsely populated tables and booths, serene sushi bar and attentive servers.
abstract: Notable offerings at K60 Japanese Steak House, which has a lively hibachi room and a quiet sushi bar, include steak teriyaki and an arrangement of sliced white tuna.

lead_paragraph: LA RUANA, Mexico — Jittery families cram into his tiny office here, daily. Hundreds more have appeared at the San Diego border 1,500 miles away, clutching an official-looking letter bearing his name, gambling that its description of the violence in this blistering stretch of central Mexico will help them gain asylum in the United States.

snippet: On his day off, the pastry chef François Payard exercises, checks up on some of his shops and spends time with his wife and friends.
lead_paragraph: The pastry chef François Payard, 47, honed his craft first in France and later at Le Bernardin and Daniel; with the entrepreneur Marlon Abela he now has a dozen patisseries and bakeries in New York, Las Vegas, Japan and South Korea. On Sundays he tries to dial it back, so he can unwind with his wife, Fernanda Capobianco, 32, owner of the bakery Vegan Divas; prepare and share good food with friends in the couple’s Turtle Bay apartment; and take his mind off business for a day.
abstract: On his day off, the pastry chef François Payard exercises, checks up on some of his shops and spends time with his wife and friends.

snippet: Lydia Lunch has transformed herself into a self-help guru. Even more surprising, she has followers.

snippet: Experience the past, present and future in this Chinese city, sampling everything from museums to street food to dancing in the park along the way.
lead_paragraph: What takes most cities eons to build, Shanghai can do overnight. Consider this: Just a decade ago, the city had four metro lines; now there are a dozen. The Jin Mao Tower was the tallest building in the neon-streaked financial center of Pudong; it has since been surpassed by the Shanghai World Financial Center and the nearly completed Shanghai Tower, which will be the second-tallest building in the world (after Dubai’s Burj Khalifa) when it’s finished next year. Still, what fascinates about this city is how little seems to have changed in the maze of lanes that have (thus far) eluded the bulldozer in the Old City or the former foreign concessions. Here, residents haggle over freshly caught fish in tiny markets or doze in lawn chairs on summer afternoons, ignoring the pounding jackhammers. Shanghai is remaking itself to become a “City of the Future,” but what’s so alluring is how much old-world character remains.
abstract: Experience the past, present and future in this Chinese city, sampling everything from museums to street food to dancing in the park along the way.

snippet: Soup, sandwiches and a sofa are just three parts of a budget-friendly stay in the Chilean capital.
lead_paragraph: “My sofa is very comfortable,” boasted Marcos, the pony-tailed, Iron Maiden-loving Chilean who had met me at the centrally located Parque O’Higgins metro stop in the Chilean capital of Santiago and was walking me to his place. “I sometimes sleep on it myself.” When you have just $100 to spend all weekend, any place will do — but his worn-in black leather sofa, paired with a thick comforter for warmth and a snow-white cat named Ixi (named for Itchy, the “Simpsons” cartoon mouse) for company, turned out to be a dream.
abstract: Soup, sandwiches and a sofa are just three parts of a budget-friendly stay in the Chilean capital.

snippet: Ellary’s Greens, which opened in the West Village in April, is not so much a restaurant as dining rehab.
lead_paragraph: “Free detox shots!” the waitress called out as she sashayed through the dining room, a tray of tiny glasses at her shoulder. The liquid in them was jungle green and wobbled. It tasted of kale and salvation, with celery and lemon for a bright-eyed, bushy-tailed finish. I downed it and waited for the world to change.

snippet: It’s a trend that seems to defy Econ 101: In early November, the price of frozen whole turkeys drops. Economists can’t agree on why.
lead_paragraph: When you do your Thanksgiving shopping this week, you will encounter two vastly different options for the centerpiece: an expensive heritage, organic, antibiotic-free, freshly killed turkey; or a relatively cheap, mass-produced, rock-solid-frozen bird. The frozen birds are a pretty attractive deal — especially because this time of year, they are unusually cheap. According to government data, frozen whole-turkey prices drop significantly every November; over the last decade, retail prices have fallen an average of 9 percent between October and November.
abstract: It’s a trend that seems to defy Econ 101: In early November, the price of frozen whole turkeys drops. Economists can’t agree on why.

snippet: At the Norimaki restaurant, a co-owner was born in Japan and the menu offers items both challenging and satisfying to Western tastes.
lead_paragraph: Norimaki maintains a low profile between a furniture store and a dry cleaner in a small shopping plaza at the center of Washington Depot. Only two small signs hang outside; one is in Japanese characters, and the other says simply “sushi.” The restaurant’s spacious, 1,000-square-foot dining area contains just 22 seats (including six at the sushi bar), with the center of the room occupied by a tree sculpture that appears to be growing through the dropped ceiling.

snippet: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers hearty vegetarian meals in a bowl (or on a plate) inspired by the Korean dish bibimbap.
lead_paragraph: These hearty vegetarian meals in a bowl (or on a plate) are inspired by the Korean dish bibimbap. I call them “Big Bowls” because they are also inspired by a popular food truck I’ve eaten at, in Portland, Ore., whose only offering is called Whole Bowl, and is a comforting bowl of brown rice, with black beans, salsa, avocado and queso blanco. The long line of people I observed at this truck confirmed for me the fact that a simple, satisfying meal with grain, protein and terrific vegetables can be worth standing in line for.
abstract: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers hearty vegetarian meals in a bowl (or on a plate) inspired by the Korean dish bibimbap.

snippet: This recipe — which calls for live marine phytoplankton and, of course, kale — might ward off that cold that’s been going around.
lead_paragraph: The first morning I visited Mariel Hemingway — actor, author, activist, granddaughter of Ernest — I watched as she and her partner, Bobby Williams, prepared a smoothie. This is part of her daily routine: because she comes from a family with a history of mental illness, addiction and suicide (a legacy explored in “Running From Crazy,” a new documentary directed by Barbara Kopple), health and wellness and the preventive measures that promote both are at the center of her life — and thus at the center of my article about her in this Sunday’s magazine.
abstract: This recipe — which calls for live marine phytoplankton and, of course, kale — might ward off that cold that’s been going around.

snippet: Mariel Hemingway has dedicated her life to the impossible: Being a healthy Hemingway.
lead_paragraph: Mariel Hemingway gets up early, perhaps as an unconscious homage to her famous grandfather, to watch the sun rise. Each morning, while still in bed, she and her live-in boyfriend, an erstwhile stuntman and actor named Bobby Williams, begin a series of predawn exercises that consist of breathing, stretching, contemplating the things they’re grateful for and visualizing the day ahead. Hemingway then makes the bed and a pot of jasmine green tea. She fills the hummingbird feeders with organic sugar water, feeds organic soy-free meal to the brood of egg-laying hens that live in her backyard and heads back to the kitchen to prepare a smoothie.
abstract: Mariel Hemingway has dedicated her life to the impossible: Being a healthy Hemingway.

snippet: Oak + Almond takes its name from the woods used in the cooking, and the restaurant has a wood oven, rotisserie and grill as well as a smoker out back.
lead_paragraph: Oak + Almond may be an offbeat name for a restaurant, but its location is familiar to many: next to the Department of Motor Vehicles in Norwalk, at the Wilton border. The owners, Jon Paul Pirraglia and his sister Johanna Gannon, worked at the Tuscan Oven, which their parents ran for years at the same site.

snippet: The chef at Fortina, a new restaurant in Armonk, spent boyhood summers on an island near Naples, and his cooking is a sort of exuberant take on tradition.
lead_paragraph: Leaving Fortina on a Friday night this autumn, a tiny patron in a pink tutu clasped hands with her parents and happily chirped her newfound word: “Ciao! Ciao! Ciao!” Passing them on the way in, a young woman in a black sequined shift and very high heels texted as she teetered toward the door. I have never in my dining experience witnessed such a seamless transition from kiddie hour to singles scene.
abstract: The chef at Fortina, a new restaurant in Armonk, spent boyhood summers on an island near Naples, and his cooking is a sort of exuberant take on tradition.

snippet: At this spot, opened in one of the city’s creative havens,  sashimi and sushi mingle with a few surprises thrown in for homegrown palates.
lead_paragraph: On a stretch of the eastern fringe of downtown Johannesburg, the Maboneng Precinct (maboneng is Sotho for “place of light”) materializes like a hipster mirage. This once-gritty enclave has been transformed into a creative haven with galleries, a popular weekly market and, of course, restaurants. Last winter the Blackanese, a pocket-size Afro-Asian spot, joined the fray with a brick-and-mortar avatar of a successful mobile stall.

snippet: Aquario is just steps from Silver Lake in West Harrison, but its owners try to stir thoughts of the Tagus River.
lead_paragraph: They don’t make them like this anymore: genteel, old-fashioned restaurants with beautiful tiles and intricate, carefully maintained murals framed by rich dark wood; with enough space among tables that conversations can remain private; where music doesn’t boom and blare; where service is calm and patrons unrushed. Aquario is such a place. That may explain why, even though the kitchen has its ups and downs, the restaurant has enjoyed two decades across the road from Silver Lake in West Harrison.
abstract: Aquario is just steps from Silver Lake in West Harrison, but its owners try to stir thoughts of the Tagus River.

snippet: At Estela, the little differences keep boredom at bay.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to take the measure of Ignacio Mattos’s cooking at Estela, which opened on East Houston Street in June, you might look at the burrata on the menu and think: no, too easy. Anyone can slap burrata on a plate and wait for the moaning to start. But order it anyway, so you can see what happens when Mr. Mattos puts this louche, voluptuous cheese on a juice cleanse.

snippet: Downtown Mount Kisco’s variety of foods now includes prime dry-aged beef.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, Mount Kisco has enjoyed a rush of restaurants drawn to its buzzing downtown. Joining the long-appreciated Thai Angel’s and the Spanish restaurant La Camelia, newcomers have been filling other ethnic niches. There’s Neo with its creative New World spins on Asian fare; Bonnie Saran’s Indian and French places, Little Kebab Station and Little Crepe Street; the Ethiopian spot Lalibela; the trattoria and cafe Via Vanti!; and Taverna Pandesia, a Greek restaurant — to mention just a few. It was only a matter of time until a steakhouse threw its hat into the ring.

snippet: Casamista, a portable humidifier, is made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass.
lead_paragraph: When designing Casamista, a portable humidifier produced by Umbra, Alan Wisniewski said he began with the idea of things that smoke: tugboat funnels, automobile tailpipes and rooftop chimneys. He settled on the last. “I thought that a traveling house with a functional chimney was a little reminder of a home away from home,” he said. The humidifier, made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass. It can also be used with water-soluble essential oils. The device comes with a USB cable and can run on AAA batteries, which are not included. Available in avocado or black for $25. Information: (800) 387-5122 or umbra.com.
abstract: Casamista, a portable humidifier, is made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass.

snippet: The City of Angels has long been the butt of many a fashion joke. But maybe there’s magic in being the totally odd outsider.
lead_paragraph: You might not realize it until you’re stuck in traffic on the 101, halfway through a whirlwind odyssey that spans a pop-up dance party in Westlake and a benefit in Bel-Air, all in an earnest attempt to understand Los Angeles’s emerging fashion scene, that there’s something very New York about the whole effort. Angelenos aren’t particularly concerned with the zeitgeist; there’s always another wave, after all. Which is one reason the fashion industry, with its rhetoric of the new and the on-trend, never put much stock in L.A.
abstract: The City of Angels has long been the butt of many a fashion joke. But maybe there’s magic in being the totally odd outsider.

It keeps the kitchen cool, feeds the family and is about as easy as can be.

snippet: The Cuddy, named for the little cabin offering shelter on a boat, serves Southern and gastro-pub dishes in a maritime setting.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy July evening, Main Street in Sag Harbor churned with a weekend crowd of locals, tourists and boating types who roamed the sidewalks, peering into the windows of packed restaurants. Feeling a little smug about our reservations, we breezed past a cluster of people waiting at the entrance to the Cuddy, which occupies a charming storefront in the heart of the village. With its rough-hewed interior softened by candlelight and a menu that leans toward hearty gastro-pub fare, it offered an appealing haven from all the activity outside.

lead_paragraph: Your job may be worrying you, or your father’s health, or your own. You may have been up at 2 that morning drafting a better ending for a long-ago memory. Every taste seems to transport you to another world, while every gesture of the staff convinces you that you live in the privileged center of this one.

snippet: Summer brings a bounty of tomatoes. Here are five ways to put them to delicious use.
lead_paragraph: Whenever July rolls around I look forward to testing recipes for what is now my annual Recipes for Health tomato week. My own tomatoes are ripening on the vine, and tomatoes are the main event at farmers’ markets. There is little room in my repertoire at this time of year for dishes that don’t include tomatoes, but this week I kept it pretty simple. As I experienced the pleasure of one of the many tomato sandwiches I made, I wondered why I bother ordering club sandwiches or anything with fresh tomatoes at any other time of year; I usually don’t but sometimes I’m confronted with a menu that doesn’t give me much of a choice.
abstract: Summer brings a bounty of tomatoes. Here are five ways to put them to delicious use.

lead_paragraph: I never could resist a tomato sandwich. It is the combination of mayonnaise, tomatoes and bread that is so compelling. I call these MLTs: mayonnaise, lettuce and tomatoes. I make a spicy mayo with chipotle adobo (my son’s favorite), and an herbal mayo with tarragon (my favorite). Play around with aioli and other flavored mayonnaises. Use whole grain bread and toast it lightly so that it doesn’t get soggy. The tomatoes should overlap in a thick layer.

snippet: The Solun Tapas Bar and Restaurant in Woodbridge, Conn., which opened in March 2012, specializes in Spanish cuisine with a twist.
lead_paragraph: Solun Tapas Bar and Restaurant is the sort of place that makes a great first impression. Its brick red color scheme, with splashes of mango yellow and a pair of wall panels partitioned into yellow, blue and red, presents a cheerful, festive air. Then there’s the can-do quality of the staff, from the welcoming hostess to the service crew. And the food, if not quite on the level of fine dining, is often prepared well enough to put diners in a good mood.

snippet: At Westport’s Rive Bistro, which faces the Saugatuck River, the water views are just one reason to visit.
lead_paragraph: Few things are more pleasant than a water view while dining, especially in summertime. And at the new Rive Bistro in Westport, it’s almost impossible not to have a water view, no matter where you are seated. Not only does the restaurant face the Saugatuck River, with wide windows on three sides, but the screened patio, with a long banquette, also has a head-on river view. If you happen to be there in the early evening, you may have the pleasure of watching scullers skim past.
abstract: At Westport’s Rive Bistro, which faces the Saugatuck River, the water views are just one reason to visit.

snippet: While the city’s beer gardens are as lively as ever, Munich is pushing to challenge Berlin as Germany’s cultural capital.
lead_paragraph: Munich has long maintained a reputation as a buttoned-up city. But these days, the Bavarian capital is cracking its conservative shell in a push to challenge Berlin as Germany’s cultural capital. In recent months, public pianos surfaced around the city from the “Play Me, I’m Yours” traveling arts project, and prestigious museums have been going through overhauls. Large-scale contemporary art installations — an Ed Ruscha billboard, a Fourth Plinth replica, a shrine to Bubbles the chimp — have been unveiled in prominent locations as part of an innovative public art initiative called “A Space Called Public” (aspacecalledpublic.de), running through September. And of course, the city’s beer gardens, a cultural institution in their own right, are as vibrant and lively as ever.
abstract: While the city’s beer gardens are as lively as ever, Munich is pushing to challenge Berlin as Germany’s cultural capital.

snippet: The chicken to end all chicken, salads upon salads and dessert — all in only a few hours.
lead_paragraph: Weekends can’t come quickly enough now that we’ve passed the Rubicon of the Fourth of July. We need them to banish memories of summer commuting and the stick and pull of work clothes at noon, when you get three feet outside your office and already regret going to the bank. Whether you’re in a friend’s backyard or a city apartment with the air-conditioner on high, the next two months are meant for barefoot padding from Friday until Monday dawn. We ought to cook to match.

snippet: Tweaking a classic while fresh green peas are in season.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks. Visit Cooking for more guacamole recipes.I’d always thought that when it comes to excellent guacamole, less is more, and that the best versions of the dip are always the most basic. Then I tried the green pea guacamole at ABC Cocina, and I changed my mind.
abstract: Tweaking a classic while fresh green peas are in season.

byline: {'original': 'By Melissa Clark', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Melissa', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Clark', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}

lead_paragraph: Adding fresh English peas to what is an otherwise fairly traditional guacamole is one of those radical moves that is also completely obvious after you taste it. The peas add intense sweetness and a chunky texture to the dip, making it more substantial on the chip. They also intensify the color of the green avocado — and help the guacamole stay that way. Pea guacamole keeps its bright hue in the fridge for a few days without turning brown around the edges. A good dose of lime juice helps this cause. This dish, a collaboration between ABC Cocina’s chef-owner, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, and his chef de cuisine, Ian Coogan, is the best kind of greenmarket tweak upon a classic.

lead_paragraph: I’M not much of a salad fan. But I’m a big believer in poetic justice, which is why I was sitting side by side with Rita Jammet in the space at the NoMad Hotel that will soon house the 20th outpost of Sweetgreen, a farm-to-table salad chain owned by her son Nicolas and two of his college friends. We were watching job applicants build towers out of marshmallows and uncooked spaghetti.

lead_paragraph: These Vietnamese-style rolls, from David Tanis, take a tiny bit of dexterity but fall under the kind of easier project cooking that yields big personal triumphs. Once you get the hang of tucking and rolling the rice-paper wrapper, the rest is simple. But, “if, despite your best efforts, your lobster rolls become unruly and fall apart, don’t despair,” he wrote back in 2013. “Just plop the perfectly good remains on a plate, drizzle with the dipping sauce and call it a rice noodle salad.”

snippet: It is more helpful to think about faith as the questions people choose to focus on, rather than the propositions observers think they must hold.
lead_paragraph: Some Sundays ago, I was part of a sermon in my university’s church. It was the kind of ecumenical church in which I’d grown up. The minister and I sat on the proscenium above the congregation and below the stained-glass windows, and spoke about the ways that evangelical Christians understood God — a subject on which I had written a book. Afterward, there was a lunch open to the community. The questions people asked as we ate our avocado-and-cheese sandwiches circled around the puzzle of belief. Why do people believe in God? What is our evidence that there is an invisible agent who has a real impact on our lives? How can those people be so confident?
abstract: It is more helpful to think about faith as the questions people choose to focus on, rather than the propositions observers think they must hold.

lead_paragraph: Here's an idea: Spend the same $30, or $50 or $100 or $300 on meat that you now spend each week or month, but buy less and buy better. You might compare this to an annual purchase of 20 $5 T-shirts made by child labor versus one of five $20 T-shirts made by better-paid and better-treated workers from organic cotton. Expensive meat from real farms is a more extreme example of this less-is-better policy. Then cook the meat differently than you used to. Take this vague interpretation of fajitas, one that focuses on grilled vegetables and makes beef a supporting player. A pound or so of tender, fatty rib-eye or sirloin goes a long way with this recipe. And it makes a lovely impression if you present it whole before slicing or chopping. You can cook everything in a cast-iron skillet (you will most likely need more than one, or you will have to cook in batches) instead of on a grill.

snippet: Cooking the grains until they splay helps them absorb the dressing.
lead_paragraph: One thing I’ve learned about cooking sturdy grains like this (and the other grains we’re working with this week) for salads is that they will absorb dressing better if you let them cook until they burst or splay. In the case of sorghum, the grain is done after 50 minutes, but if you let it go for another 10 the grains will burst and the lemon juice and olive oil won’t slide off.
abstract: Cooking the grains until they splay helps them absorb the dressing.

snippet: Chewy, hearty grains like spelt, kamut and farro, often sold as wheat berries, are a relatively recent arrival on American plates.
lead_paragraph: “Ancient grains” seems to be a new buzz phrase in the world of whole foods (or maybe I’ve been missing something for a long time). The words describe grain varieties that have been eaten as staples for hundreds if not thousands of years. Some of these have fed people in far-flung parts of the world for a very long time but have been of little interest as a food on the American market. Grains like sorghum have been grown here but fed primarily to animals, whereas sorghum has been a staple for centuries in Africa and India.
abstract: Chewy, hearty grains like spelt, kamut and farro, often sold as wheat berries, are a relatively recent arrival on American plates.

lead_paragraph: Sorghum reminds me of Israeli couscous, spherical and about the same size. Like Israeli couscous, it’s good with brothy stews. I love the way the firm, round grains stand up against the soft, brothy beans in this bean and amaranth stew. You can find amaranth at many farmers’ markets and Asian markets. The beautiful purple and green leaves are high in anthocyanins, known for their antioxidant properties, as are black beans. Substitute baby spinach if you can’t find it.

snippet: At Spicy Green Bean in Glastonbury, the chef-owner, Kathy Denisiewicz, emphasizes taste and value over culinary technique.
lead_paragraph: Let me begin my salute to B.Y.O.B. restaurants with a miser’s confession: I almost never spend more than $50 on wine. Whatever your particular price ceiling, bringing your own wine to a restaurant makes sterling sense. That $50 bottle on a restaurant’s wine list probably cost them $19, while they’d charge $100 for the $50 bottle you’re bringing. With the money you save, you can order a lot of extra starters.
abstract: At Spicy Green Bean in Glastonbury, the chef-owner, Kathy Denisiewicz, emphasizes taste and value over culinary technique.

lead_paragraph: I add a little avocado to this cucumber soup to keep it from separating, a trick I learned from Jason Weiner, the chef and an owner of Almond Restaurants. The only requirement is that the soup be perfectly smooth, so use a blender. It should also not be too thick to sip, so add a little water if necessary. And try to keep your ingredients as cold as possible.

snippet: With Red Hen, the chef Shelley Deproto moves away from her usual style and opens her menu, saying “If it’s Cuban one day, it’s Cuban.”
lead_paragraph: On the last day of 2011, the chef Shelley Deproto packed up her kitchen and closed Lupo, the Mediterranean-style restaurant she had owned and operated in Chester since 2003. Her new venture, Red Hen Restaurant in Old Saybrook, opened last fall. The name is borrowed from a children’s book and evokes no particular culinary culture. This is intentional. After 8 ½ years of hewing to Mediterranean cuisine, Ms. Deproto wants to take inspiration where she finds it.
abstract: With Red Hen, the chef Shelley Deproto moves away from her usual style and opens her menu, saying “If it’s Cuban one day, it’s Cuban.”

snippet: “Happy, Happy, Happy” by Phil Robertson is No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list — the second best seller spawned by the reality show “Duck Dynasty.”
lead_paragraph: DUCK SEASON: Phil Robertson, the backwoods Louisiana patriarch and hunting entrepreneur who stars on the A&E reality show “Duck Dynasty,” rules the hardcover nonfiction list this week — his memoir, “Happy, Happy, Happy” (written with Mark Schlabach), is new at No. 1. It’s not the first best seller the show has spawned, either: “The Duck Commander Family,” by Phil’s son Willie and daughter-in-law Korie (with Schlabach again), is at No. 7 in its sixth week, riding the coattails of a season finale that drew 9.6 million viewers last month. “Happy, Happy, Happy” takes its title from Robertson’s catchphrase, and presents itself as a rustic guide to the good life — one chapter, “Redneck Caviar,” declares that “Rule No. 11 for living happy, happy, happy” is to “suck the head of a crawfish (you’ll want to do it again and again).” Part of the Robertsons’ charm is that they seem genuinely well adjusted, like the Waltons’ hairier cousins; every episode ends with a family prayer and a dinner prepared by Phil’s wife, Kay, whom he married when he was 16 and she was 15. “If you can find a nice, pretty country girl who can cook and carries her Bible,” he advises readers, “now, there’s a woman. She might even be ugly, but if she cooks squirrels and dumplings, then that’s the woman you go after.”
abstract: “Happy, Happy, Happy” by Phil Robertson is No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list — the second best seller spawned by the reality show “Duck Dynasty.”

snippet: Five years, five boroughs and five restaurants: A couple’s unusual dining tour is capped with dinner at Alder, the chef Wylie Dufresne’s newest restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Consider the crush of publicity and the lines that have formed on Second Avenue outside Wylie Dufresne’s newest restaurant. Note that Mr. Dufresne and his muttonchops are television celebrities. Add that last week Mr. Dufresne won the James Beard Award for New York’s Best Chef. So how refreshing it was that not everybody in Alder’s rustic-chic dining room on Wednesday was caught up on the place’s reputation. One food-loving couple transplanted from San Diego and Venice (Italy) came for their own adventure: the end of a five-borough birthday tour. They were delightfully unaware of WD-50, Mr. Dufresne’s celebrated flagship. And instead of debating the hype, they reveled in the whimsy of the evening and Alder’s modernist spin on comfort food, savoring their journey as much as the dehydrated pastrami.
abstract: Five years, five boroughs and five restaurants: A couple’s unusual dining tour is capped with dinner at Alder, the chef Wylie Dufresne’s newest restaurant.

snippet: At Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar, a bright dining room with avant-garde artwork sets the backdrop for tapas dishes that are divided between traditional and modern takes on Spanish finger food.
lead_paragraph: Widespread and varied as tapas have become in Connecticut, the arrival of Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar in Danbury in January serves as a refreshing reminder of the heights — and delights — this quintessential Spanish bar food can achieve. Ibiza is the fourth in a growing family of like-named restaurants owned by Ignacio Blanco (other Ibizas are in New Haven, Hamden and Northampton, Mass.). In contrast to the understated, rustic elegance of Mr. Blanco’s earlier venture in Norwalk, Maison Galicia (renamed Meigas and later sold), Ibiza brings a vibrant Barcelona-meets-Caribbean splash of bold colors to the dining experience.
abstract: At Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar, a bright dining room with avant-garde artwork sets the backdrop for tapas dishes that are divided between traditional and modern takes on Spanish finger food.

snippet: This getaway tucked into the country’s northwest corner features everything from neo-Classical buildings to a tropical cloud forest to dishes made with tender llama meat.
lead_paragraph: Argentina’s northwestern Salta Province has long been famous for its spectacular scenery of Andean peaks, red-rock valleys and vineyards, but its central metropolis, the city of Salta, has emerged only in the last few years as a bright spot on the tourist map. Founded in 1582 by the Spanish commander Hernando de Lerma, the city has traditionally served primarily as a supply center for the Spanish mining sites located in present-day Bolivia. A concerted effort to encourage new hotels, restaurants and shops is now paying off in a stream of visitors attracted to Salta’s updated colonial charm. Today, the old city center is recognized as a jewel-box-size getaway, perfect for exploring on foot and finally appreciated for its rich cultural offerings, grand neo-Classical buildings and thriving night life.
abstract: This getaway tucked into the country’s northwest corner features everything from neo-Classical buildings to a tropical cloud forest to dishes made with tender llama meat.

snippet: Gaucho Grill, an Argentine steakhouse with Italian flair, is elegant without being trendy or self-conscious.
lead_paragraph: The first empanada I ever had was made by an Argentine friend in college. That country’s version of the small South American meat patty features a substantial beef filling tucked into a flaky shell, and it was love at first bite. I’ve had dozens and dozens of empanadas since, made in almost as many styles, but it was the one from Gaucho Grill, an Argentine restaurant that opened in White Plains last year, that gave me the biggest thrill since my first.
abstract: Gaucho Grill, an Argentine steakhouse with Italian flair, is elegant without being trendy or self-conscious.

snippet: The pleasures at the Library at the Public are cumulative, the sum of small, quiet gestures by Andrew Carmellini and Michael Oliver.
lead_paragraph: It is forever after-hours at the Library at the Public, a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled last fall from the upper recesses of the lobby at the newly renovated Public Theater, reachable by a discreetly bland stairwell. (Look to your left.) The lamps are tepid, verging on gaslight, barely adequate for reading the menu, let alone one of the books lodged at calculated intervals along the walls.

snippet: Guapo Cocina Mexicana, in Yonkers, is owned by Edi Dedi, Ferdinando Paterra, Robert Leggio and Paskual Dedi, the team behind the pioneering Zuppa, just around the corner.
lead_paragraph: On our first visit to Guapo Cocina Mexicana, two of my guests stood outside and peered through the plate-glass window while I fed the parking meter. By the time I joined them, they wore big grins: the manager of the restaurant, sensing an opportunity, had come out into the cold and handed them coupons for free margaritas. It was this mix of hustle and charm offensive — and lively, well-priced, authentic Mexican dishes — that had us developing a little crush on Guapo.
abstract: Guapo Cocina Mexicana, in Yonkers, is owned by Edi Dedi, Ferdinando Paterra, Robert Leggio and Paskual Dedi, the team behind the pioneering Zuppa, just around the corner.

lead_paragraph: Once upon a time there was Once Upon a Moose, a quirky little landmark of a lunch place that you took your mother to for tea and an omelet after browsing the used books in one of the eclectic cliff-top shops down the street. It had a run for decades in its prime corner spot in tiny Sea Cliff; then the site was briefly home to Olives by the Sea, a boho tapas bistro.

lead_paragraph: EL CARGADERO, Mexico — The pretty houses in the hills here, with their bright paint and new additions, clearly display the material benefits of having millions of workers move to the United States over the past few decades. But these simple homes also reveal why another huge exodus would be unlikely: the bulk of them are empty.

lead_paragraph: State Bird Provisions on Fillmore Street in San Francisco is the brainchild of a wife-and-husband team of native Californians, Nicole Krasinski and Stuart Brioza. At the restaurant, food is brought out on carts, as it is in dim-sum parlors. Although the concept is familiar to everyone at this point, these are laden not with the mostly brown and steamed food common to dim-sum places but with gorgeous, far-out, inventively served creations. Many of their dishes were too complicated for me to deal with. This dish, though, is  representative of the restaurant's food, highly flavored, unusual, delicious.

snippet: The dishes at Coriander, compared with those at most Indian restaurants, seem lighter, but each dish’s flavors and complexities remain in full force.
lead_paragraph: In these days of trendy fusion this and fusion that, diners often have to guess what lies ahead when a restaurant claims modernity. In the case of Coriander, in Larchmont, several factors combine to create a modern feel. The décor is low key: a contemporary beige and charcoal color scheme, brightened by a row of charming white lanterns in the aisle that leads to the dining room. A small handful of cross-legged mustachioed Rajasthani figurines and a dramatic Shiva as Nataraja the cosmic dancer set the Indian theme.
abstract: The dishes at Coriander, compared with those at most Indian restaurants, seem lighter, but each dish’s flavors and complexities remain in full force.

snippet: Testing the new $400 juicer from Hurom.
lead_paragraph: If you find it hard to live in this decade without embarking on a juice fast, you might want to upgrade your juice-extracting technology. That’s what drove this reporter to try the Premium Slow Juicer/Smoothie Maker from Hurom ($400). Like previous versions, the machine crushes rather than whirls its contents, which uses less energy, obtains more juice and preserves more nutrients, the company says. This model also has a lever to control pulp.

snippet: At Harlem Public on upper Broadway, three girlfriends celebrated one’s acceptance to a doctoral program and traded guy talk over craft beers and burgers.
lead_paragraph: On upper Broadway, where hair salons and barbershops bustle well into the evening and markets sell plantains in outdoor bins, a bar with incongruous chic invites the neighborhood in for a beer. Step inside Harlem Public on Broadway at 149th Street and the trendy touches borrowed from elsewhere in the city are easy to spot. There are 16 taps of craft beer and about a dozen whiskeys from local distilleries. The décor is made from reclaimed wood and corrugated metal. An ambitious menu includes avocado fries, a peanut butter burger and a decadent grilled cheese sandwich. Right now the cast iron gas fireplace, which took months of wrangling to install, is on the fritz. But the six-month-old bar generates its own heat, humming to an alternative soundtrack. And on Feb. 24, it will start brunch service.
abstract: At Harlem Public on upper Broadway, three girlfriends celebrated one’s acceptance to a doctoral program and traded guy talk over craft beers and burgers.

snippet: Zac Posen, a new judge on “Project Runway,” uses the time to experiment with fabric and get inspired by his playlist.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, fresh out of college, Zac Posen was a wunderkind of the fashion industry, starting his own label and making his name among the established brands. Now, at 32, after some setbacks, he is reintroducing himself to the public as a judge on “Project Runway,” which began its 11th season last month. He will also show his fall collection at the Plaza on Feb. 10. Mr. Posen lives in SoHo with his partner, Christopher Niquet, 34, a stylist and fashion editor, and “three lovely ladies”: Tina Turner, a poodle; Betty Blue, a dapple miniature dachshund; and Candy Darling, an English cream miniature dachshund.

snippet: This year’s Oscars are a hotbed for animation lovers, with five nominees for best animated film instead of the usual three, and an animator hosting the ceremony.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At one minute 45 seconds, with credits, “Fresh Guacamole“ is the briefest film ever nominated for an Oscar. It’s a stop-motion short in which that popular avocado dish is remade with different ingredients, starting with a grenade in place of the avocado. The short, made by an animator known as PES, is a sequel of sorts to “Western Spaghetti,” a stop-motion recipe of pickup sticks pasta and Rubik’s cube garlic. It’s the first film PES, born Adam Pesapane, submitted for Oscar consideration, a process that presented some challenges for a filmmaker whose work usually lives on YouTube.
abstract: This year’s Oscars are a hotbed for animation lovers, with five nominees for best animated film instead of the usual three, and an animator hosting the ceremony.
